summary: The document comprises historical records of the Directorate of Science and Technology within the CIA, disclosed under the President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Act of 1992. It details mission statements and organizational structures of key offices such as the Office of Special Activities, the National Photographic Interpretation Center (NPIC), and the Office of Technical Service from 1959 to 1975. These records elucidate the offices' roles in scientific and technical intelligence, alongside their contributions to research and development and CIA operational support.
key_findings: The Directorate of Science and Technology played a pivotal role in scientific and technical intelligence, encompassing research and development and operational support for the CIA.

Notable offices within the Directorate included the Office of Special Activities, which managed highly sensitive technical collection programs, and the National Photographic Interpretation Center (NPIC), specializing in photographic intelligence.
The documents illustrate the Directorate's structural and functional evolution, mirroring advancements in technology and shifts in intelligence priorities.
The Office of Technical Service was instrumental in providing operational support by developing and implementing technical equipment and methods for clandestine operations.
keywords: President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Act
